a b s t r a c t
Plant essential oils (EOs) possesses remarkable antimicrobial efficacy and therefore have great potential as an alternative of health hazardous synthetic preservatives. In spite of marvellous efficacy, their application yet not widely used by the food industries due to some of the major intrinsic obstacles viz., low water solubility, bioavailability, volatility and stability in the food system. The recent advancement in nanotechnology has potential to address these existing obstacles of EOs as preservatives in the food system. The applications of nanomaterials as a carrier agent of EOs recently gain momentum of interest by the food industries to improve their shelf-life and preservatives efficacy at low doses. Nanoemulsions, microemulsions, solid-lipid nanoparticles and liposomes are some of the currently used encapsulation strategies to encapsulate plant bioactive compounds. In this review, we explored the potential application of nanoencapsulated plant EOs as novel source of food preservatives. In addition, the prospects, existing limitations and future research direction for their commercialization are also discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The growing interest of consumers towards the green consumerism has resulted in the use of plant-derived natural products as an eco-friendly food preservative. Since most of the currently used synthetic preservatives are restricted to their use or under evaluation in view of resistance and adverse impact on the health and environment (Prakash & Kiran, 2016). Therefore, the food industries are currently looking towards some novel and safer approaches for food preservation to address the challenges to the existing synthetic preservatives. In this context, traditionally used EOs and their bioactive compounds possess inherent antimicrobial activity against food-born pathogen could offer a novel source for food preservation. Hence, in past few decades, the EOs and their bioactive compounds have been extensively studied for their antimicrobial efficacy against food borne pathogen viz., bacteria, molds and their associated toxins. Some of the EOs and their bioactive compounds viz., Mentha piperita, Pimenta officinalis, Matricaria chamomilla, Cuminum cyminum, Coriandrum sativum, Ocimum basilicum, carvacrol, carvone, cinnamaldehyde, citral, pcymene, eugenol, limonene, menthol, linalool, vanillin, citral and thymol have already been listed in Generally Recognised As Safe (GRAS) by the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations (U.S. Code of Federal Regulations, 2016). In spite of tremendous in vitro antimicrobial efficacy, most of the EOs fail to exert their full preservative potential in food system due to some of the major intrinsic obstacle viz., low water solubility, bioavailability, volatility, and stability (Kujur, Kiran, Dubey, & Prakash, 2017). The recent advances in nanotechnology could successfully address these challenges with controlled release of EOs to deliver their boost effect at the right time and the right place. In addition, nanomaterials (size< 100 nm) can be used as a carrier to mask the undesirable aroma effect of EOs and optimised their interaction with food components (Donsì, Annunziata, Sessa, & Ferrari, 2011). The use of nanomaterials as the delivery agent of EOs represents a promising approach to improve the quality, safety and functionality of food products. Hence, application of nanotechnology in the food industry is one of the fastest growing fields in the past few years.
The review summarised the up-to-date account on the potential of EOs as food preservatives. In addition, the prospective application of nanotechnology, critical challenges and future perspective for the development of EOs based preservative have been discussed.
2. Essential oils as food preservatives: current status, challenges, and significance
2.1. Essential oils as food preservatives: an outlook of recent study
The historical records revealed that the EOs play a remarkable role in traditional medicine. However, their application as a food additive is the recent growing interest in view of their strong antimicrobial and antioxidant properties (Calo, Crandall, Bryan, & Ricke, 2015). The first scientific records about antimicrobial efficacy of cinnamon oil against spores of Anthrax bacilliwere reported in the 1880s (Tajkarimi, Ibrahim, & Cliver, 2010). In general, EOs are the complexmixture of varied secondarymetabolites viz., terpenes, terpenoids, phenylpropenes, aldehydes, ketones, ethers, and phenolics often showed strong antimicrobial and antioxidant activity. Since the EOs are the complex mixture of compounds their application can effectively manage food born pathogen viz., bacteria, molds, and associated toxins without promoting the acquisition of resistance (Kavanaugh & Ribbeck, 2012; Prakash et al., 2012; 2013; 2014). Further, most of the EOs have low mammalian toxicity and ephemeral in naturewhichmake them relatively safe for the health
and environment (Calo et al., 2015; Prakash & Kiran, 2016). Therefore, in the past few decades, EOs obtained from traditionally used aromatic plant families viz., Lamiaceae, Rutaceae, Myrtaceae, Zingiberaceae, and Asteraceae have been extensively explored for their efficacy against food borne pathogen. The literature review studies over the past five year revealed that EOs and their bioactive compound exhibited strong efficacy against food born bacteria (Kavanaugh&Ribbeck, 2012), molds (Kiran, Kujur, & Prakash, 2016; Prakash et al., 2013; 2014; 2015) and oxidative deterioration (Kiran et al., 2016; Prakash et al., 2013; 2014; 2015). The list of some traditionally used EOs kept in GRAS category, their bioactivity and elucidated major compounds are summarised in Table 1.
2.2. Challenges contributing to decline the use of plant essential oil as food preservatives
Although, a huge number of EOs and their bioactive compounds have been approved by the regulatory agencies such as European Commission and United States Food and Drug Administration for their intended use as the flavouring agent in the food products (Hyldgaard, Mygind,&Meyer, 2012). EOs have various intrinsic and extrinsic critical challenges which hindered their application as food preservatives. The scarcity of raw materials, chemotypic variation, inconsistent efficacy, lack of molecular mechanism of action, adverse impact on food matrix, low water solubility, high cost and threat of biodiversity losses are some of the major challenges to EOs based preservatives (Prakash & Kiran, 2016). In addition, collection and identification of plants and quality assessment of raw materials need specialists who become increasingly rare (Bucar, Wube, & Schmid, 2013). Furthermore, quantity of EOs obtained from the raw materials often insufficient for their commercial application. The lipophilic and volatile components of EOs are susceptible to polymerization and oxidative deterioration during storage that may change the functional composition of active constituents as well as antimicrobial properties (Turek & Stintzing, 2013). The food matrix (fat, protein, carbohydrates, water activity, salt contents and pH) together with extrinsic factors such as temperature, gaseous composition, and types of microorganisms could reduce the antimicrobial potency of EOs (Calo et al., 2015; Gutierrez, Barry-Ryan, & Bourke, 2008; Rattanachaikunsopon & Phumkhachorn, 2010). In food system EOs may bind to lipids, proteins and carbohydrates, thus require high doses to achieve the antimicrobial effect that may change the sensory threshold levels (Weiss, Loeffler, & Terjung, 2015). The intense aroma of most of EOs even at low dose may negatively influence the organoleptic properties (flavour, color, taste and texture) of applicable food items leads to decrease in consumer acceptance (Noori, Zeynali, & Almasi, 2018). Due to the aforementioned challenges, the interest in EOs based preservatives has been gradually declining in past decade.
2.3. Renewal of the interest in the use of essential oils based food preservatives
In view of the recent consumer awareness towards safe and healthy food items with minimal synthetic food preservatives the global demands of plant-based food preservatives increasing day by day. Further, the recent reports on the suspected negative impact of some of the currently used food preservatives compelled the industries to look their sustainable alternatives in the near future. For instance, the food preservatives viz., propyl gallate, butylated hydroxyanisole, (BHA), butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT), tert-butylhydroquinone, (TBHQ), nitrates, and nitrites have been reported to have potential increased risk for cancer. In this context, EOs of aromatic plants possess strong antimicrobial and antioxidant potential could be used as natural preservatives to realize the consumer demand for safe, healthy and nutritious food (Prakash& Kiran, 2016). The recent advancement in modern science and technology viz., combinatorial chemistry, metabolomics, and nanotechnology generate new solutions for raw materials production and expanded the application domain of EOs and other natural products in food industries. Furthermore, the recent advancement in extraction techniques such as supercritical fluid extraction, microwave ultrasonic-assisted extraction, microwave steam distillation and steam diffusion etc., enhanced the extraction yield and quality of EOs (Bucar et al., 2013). Eco-SMART is one of the world's leading EO-based industries, that has developed several bioactive formulation based on EOs and their bioactive compounds viz., Eugenol-Tween® and Eugenol ethoxylate, ActiVin™, Pycnogenol® and Herbalox® (Prakash & Kiran, 2016). The global demands of safe products are increasing day by day, and it is expected that the EOs market will reach USD 11.67 billion by 2022 (Grand View Research, 2015). Therefore, industries are looking again towards the EOs for the formulation of plant-based food preservatives to address the resistance, health and other environmental issues related to synthetic preservatives.

potential of plant essential oils: from in vitro to food system
The concept of nanotechnology had been introduced by Richard Feynman (1959); later on in 1974 Nario Taniguchi coined the term nanotechnology and used it for the manipulation of particles size less than 1 mm. It deals with the art of science to reduce thematerial size ranging from 1 to 100 nm which could be used as coating material/carrier agent for the plant-based bioactive compounds. The reduction in particle size increases the surface-to-volume ratio which enhances their reactivity and offers many unique and novel features. In general, there are two hypotheses for the formulation of the nanostructure of different materials i.e. Top down and Bottom up techniques. The Top down technique deals with the nano-size range compounds produced from the larger size materials, while
in the case of Bottom up techniques nano-size range material could be formed by self-assembly of atom by atom, molecule by molecule or atoms and molecules depends upon their natural properties (Quintanilla-Carvajal et al., 2010). In the past few decades, nanotechnology has become a major focus of research activity in the field of pharma industry; while in the food sector this concept is a recent growing interest by the Industries as a delivery agent of plant-based preservative and nutraceuticals. Nanoencapsulation of EOs offers numerous advantages such as ease of handling, stability, protection against oxidation, enhanced distribution, solubility, controlled release, with less or no adverse effect on organoleptic properties of applicable food items with enhanced bioavailability. Hence, the use of nanotechnology to develop EOs based preservatives could enhance their effectiveness in the food system.
Donsì et al. (2011) reported that the nanoencapsulated volatile compounds (terpenes and D-limonene) exhibited enhanced antibacterial activity against food born bacteria viz., Lactobacillus delbrueckii and Escherichia coli with minimal alteration of the organoleptic properties of treated food items. Jamil et al. (2016) studied the antimicrobial efficacy of cardamom oil encapsulated in chitosan-based nano-particles and reported that encapsulated oil exhibit excellent antimicrobial potential against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus. Hosseini, Zandi, Rezaei, & Farahmandghavi (2013) synthesised and characterised the chitosan based nanoparticles as a carrier agent for the oregano EO and recommend its use as encapsulating material for the EOs based antimicrobials. Beyki et al. (2014) prepared chitosan-cinnamic acid nanogel as a carrier agent for Mentha piperita oil and studied their antimicrobial activity under sealed and non-sealed condition. They reported that encapsulated oil successfully retained its antimicrobial potential in non sealed condition. Hence, chitosan-based nanoencapsulation could be used to reduce the evaporation rate of EOs during their application in open environment. Wu, Luo, & Wang (2012) prepared the nanoformulations of thymol and carvacrol using zein nanoparticles and reported that the encapsulation allows better dispersion inwater with enhances activity against foodborn pathogen and free radical deterioration. Table 2 represent the efficacy of encapsulated EOs and their bioactive compounds against food borne pathogen.
3.1. Nanocarrier as a delivery agent for plant essential oils in food system: current status
Nanotechnology has become an increasingly important technology for food sector especially to boost the preservative potential of EOs. Encapsulatingmaterials viz., chitosan cyclodextrin, albumin, globulin, maltodextrin, and starch, etc., have been used in the different delivery systems to protect EOs from intrinsic and extrinsic factors such as pH, water activity, enzymatic degradation, temperature, relative humidity, and storage environment. A wide range of strategies has been proposed for the nano-formulation viz., polymeric nanoparticles; solid-lipid nanoparticles and nanostructured lipid carriers; Liquid crystalline systems, nano/microemulsions, and liposomes. However, these methods have their own limitations viz., physical and chemical stability, capsule compatibility, high cost of production and the lack of food-grade coating materials. Therefore, before the formulation or synthesis of encapsulating material the factors viz., polarity of active compounds, solubility, volatility, availability and food matrix composition must be taken into consideration. In general, the EOs are the complex volatile mixture of lipophilic compounds; therefore, lipidbased systems viz., nano and microemulsions, solid-lipid nanoparticles, and liposomes have been extensively studied to explore their efficacy as encapsulating materials for EOs based food preservatives. A systematic view of the preparation of different nanoformulation and their expected significance in food system has been presented in Fig. 1.
3.2. Liposomes based strategies
Liposomes are the self-assembled spherical colloidal structure made up of phospholipid bilayers which enclose either aqueous or lipid soluble material (Zeisig & Cammerer, 2001). The basis of the liposome formation is the hydrophilic-hydrophobic interaction between phospholipids and water-soluble materials. Due to amphipathic nature, the phospholipids have the ability to form a membranous structure on dispersion in aqueous solutions, their polar heads interact with the aqueous environment, and long apolar aliphatic chains interact with one another (Bozzuto& Molinari, 2015). Owing to these properties they can be used as carrier agents for both lipophilic and hydrophilic molecules. (Atrooz, 2011; Benech, Kheadr, Laridi, Lacroix, & Fliss, 2002). Depends on the preparation techniques and layer formation several groups of the liposomal system have been proposed viz., small unilamellar vesicles, large unilamellar vesicles, and multilamellar vesicles (Bozzuto & Molinari, 2015). Valencia-Sullca, Jimenez, Jimenez, Atares, Vargas, & Chiralt (2016) prepared the antimicrobial film of eugenol and cinnamon leaf EO using lecithin liposomes and reported that liposome-based encapsulation exhibit improved film extensibility with increased water vapour barrier capacity over the uncapsulated compounds. Van Vuuren, du Toit, Parry, Pillay, and Choonara (2010) stated that the diastearoyl phosphatidylcholine and diastearoyl phosphatidylethanolamine liposomes could be used as the delivery agent of Artemisia afra, Eucalyptus globules, and Melaleuca alternifolia EOs to extend their shelf-life as an antimicrobial agent. Detoni et al. (2012) prepared the liposome (multi and unilamellar vesicle) based carrier agent for the Zanthoxylum tinguassuiba EO and reported that the carrier agent successfully enhanced the thermal stability and bioactivity of EO.
3.3. Nanoemulsions based strategies
Emulsions system is one of the most widely used traditional technique in food industries to change the texture, flavour, and
appearance of foods products viz., milk, cream, mayonnaise, beverages, and sauces, etc. It consists liquid-liquid dispersions of two completely/partially immiscible compounds in which one being dispersed in the form of droplets to another one. To improve the stability of emulsion system different suitable emulsifiers are generally added which encircle the dispersed droplets to reduce interfacial tension or increase droplet-droplet repulsion (Solans, Izquierdo, Nolla, Azemar, & Garcia-Celma, 2005; Tadros, Izquierdo, Esquena, & Solans, 2004). Due to the advent of modern technology such as spontaneous emulsification and ultra-highpressure homogenizers the droplet size of emulsion (oil/water/ emulsifier) could reduce in the micro or nano-size range (<100 nm). Nanoemulsions exhibited better efficacy in term of appearance, stability, texture, and activity compared to the microemulsion. Donsì, Annunziata, Vincensi, and Ferrari (2012) prepared nanoemulsion containing EOs based compounds viz., carvacrol, limonene, and cinnamaldehyde using different emulsifier agents viz., lecithin, pea proteins, sugar ester, Tween 20 and glycerol monooleate and studied their antimicrobial efficacy against Escherichia coli, Lactobacillus delbrueckii and Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The results revealed that the antimicrobial efficacy of nanoemulsion is influenced by the emulsifier agent; hence, before its use as carrier agent there is strict need of rational design to obtain the desirable antimicrobial effect in the food system. Almadiy, Nenaah, Al Assiuty, Moussa, & Mira (2016) reported that the nanoemulsions of Achillea biebersteinii, Achillea fragrantissima, Achillea santolina and Achillea millefolium exhibited enhanced antimicrobial activity over the free oils against food-borne bacteria staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Salmonella enteritidis. Therefore, currently, nanoemulsion-based encapsulation system gain momentum of interest to the food industries as carrier agent for EOs based preservatives.
3.4. Solid-lipid nanoparticles based strategies
Solid lipid nanoparticles are the colloidal carriers used as an alternative system to the existing traditional carriers such as emulsions, liposomes, and polymeric micro and nanoparticles. It consists biocompatible and biodegradable lipids which are in solid form at room temperature. This system has been widely used as a carrier agent for chemically unstable hydrophobic compounds. It forms a lipophilic matrix by homogenizing the oil and water phase together along with the hydrophilic emulsifier (Müller, M€ader, & Gohla, 2000). Solid-lipid nanoparticles could greatly improve the physical and chemical stability and bioavailability of hydrophobic antimicrobials such as EOs and their bioactive compounds compared to liquid droplets/or conventional emulsion system (Shidhaye, Vaidya, Sutar, Patwardhan, & Kadam, 2008). Lai, Wissing, Müller, & Fadda (2006) prepared two different solidlipid nanoparticles as delivery agent of Artemisia arborescens EO using Compritol 888 ATO, Poloxamer 188 and Miranol Ultra C32. The results revealed that the solid-lipid nanoparticles exhibited high physical stability with reduce rate evaporation of EOs. Al-Haj et al. (2010) reported that solid lipid nanoparticle containing Nigell sativa EO exhibited high physical stability up to three months and recommend its application as suitable carrier agent for EOs. Although this system of encapsulation has strong potential as the carrier for antimicrobial; the low loading capacity, chances of the expulsion of the coated material are some of the technical disadvantageous with this system. Therefore, currently, the liquid lipids or mixture of different lipids are used to create a matrix system to generate the nanostructure lipid carriers for antimicrobial EOs.
3.5. Techniques used for the characterization of encapsulated materials
The particle size and surface area of encapsulating materials plays an important role in controlling the release rate of EOs through the capsule core. Therefore, irreversible aggregation and
chemical instability of nanoformulation must be avoided. Hence, it is necessary to convert the nanosuspensions into the solid form (Nakagawa, Surassmo, Min, & Choi, 2011). Currently, freeze drying and spray drying methods are employed for the drying of nanosuspensions to control and sustain the release rate of bioactive volatile compounds in solid form. Lyophilization or freeze drying
technique is widely used in food industries to remove the water vapour from the nanoparticles. This process may negatively alter the chemical properties of the coating material; hence, the suitable cryoprotectant (Glucose, mannose, maltose and trehalose) must be added to preserve the overall quality. Contrary to freeze drying, the spray-drying technique is rapid, cost effective and straightforward process which can produce bulk amount at the commercial level. In addition, spray drying leads to the formation of spherical shaped particles; thereby provide a wider surface area to the encapsulated core material. Therefore, in past few decades, it is widely used in food industries to encapsulate various food additives viz., flavors, vitamins, minerals, colorants, and oils to extend their shelf-life stability with enhanced functionality. Further, the characterization of stable dried nano-formulation is needed to speculate the positive or negative impact of nanomaterials on the food system, health, and environment (Royal Society 2004). Therefore, characterization of nanoparticles (chemical nature, aggregation, dispersion, sorption, size, structure, and shape) should be done before their recommendation as an antimicrobial in the food system. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) are two widely used techniques to investigate the internal and surface structure profile of micro-and nanostructures respectively. Furthermore, the spectroscopic technique viz., static light scattering, dynamic light-scattering (DLS), neutron scattering, small-angle neutron scattering, nuclear magnetic resonance, and X-ray diffraction (XRD) are some of the widely used to characterize the nanoformulation.

sections.heading: 4. Mechanism of action of nanoencapsulated plant essential oils against food borne microbes
sections.text:
Nanoencapsulated EOs and their bioactive compounds exhibiting strong antimicrobial activity could be used as safer alternative of synthetic ones (Donsì et al., 2012). Since, EOs are the volatile cocktail of several bioactive compounds (terpenes, terpenoids, phenylpropenes and phenolics) that may target different site at a time and disturb the homeostasis of microbes, therefore, chance of resistance development is negligible (Prakash, Kedia, Mishra, & Dubey, 2015). The mechanism of action of EOs depends on their inherent biochemical profile and their ratio in crude EOs and it has a cascade of reactions. In general, EOs negatively interact with biochemical and structural attribute of microbes lead to disturbance of functioning of cell membrane, cytoplasm content, enzymes and proteins associated with normal functioning of cell, thereby, disturbed the microbial metabolism and lead to cell death (Donsì et al., 2012; Calo et al., 2015; Kujur et al., 2017). The nanomaterials (chitosan, dextran, cellulose, starch, alginate and cyclodextrin etc.) used as carrier agents also exhibits antimicrobial properties by the disruption of membrane potential, reactive oxygen species generation and altering themetabolic process (AlvarezPaino, Mu~noz-Bonilla, & Fern andez-García, 2017). The small size (nano-range 10 9m) of nanoencapsulated EOs increases the surface area per volume unit; hence, they interact more efficiently with cell membrane causing cell death at optimal doses (Gupta, Eral, Hatton, & Doyle, 2016). The delivery system is capable to transport the EOs across the cell membrane and then release the EOs that may act on inner side of cytoplasmic membrane (Donsì et al., 2012). In addition, encapsulating materials make shield between the EOs and food matrix, and deliver them at specific targeted sites (water-rich phases where the microorganisms preferentially proliferate) with enhanced stability and dispersability. Furthermore, the EOs may act synergistically with the carrier agent posses antimicrobial activity, thereby enhanced the antimicrobial activity of nanoencapsulated EOs. Schematic representation of speculated mode of action of nanoencapsulated EOs in
food matrix and their various targeted site is exemplified in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 5. Nanotechnology in food industries: perspective and challenges
sections.text:
Nanotechnology is an emerging area of food science and technology that holds great promise in food industry. The nano-particle size with large surface area gives distinctive feature to the nanomaterials and makes them more effective and suitable in the food system. Nanoencapsulated antimicrobial (phytochemicals, alkaloids, EOs etc.) and antioxidants could reduce the microbial contamination in the food system with enhanced organoleptic properties (flavour, color, taste and texture). A range of product based on nanotechnology is already being used in different food sectors viz., food processing, quality control, nutritional supplements, antimicrobial and smart packaging system (Chellaram et al., 2014). In view of promising results and applications, the use of nanotechnology can play remarkable role in the development of programmable food, a futuristic concept promising the consumers to have their food of desired color, flavor, and nutrition (Ravichandran, 2010). Hence, the nano-technology may provide innovative and economical development routes for food safety in the near future.
In spite of tremendous opportunity and potential, the application of the nano-based product in the food system is not fully approved by the regulatory authorities. Lack of knowledge about the potential unforeseen risks, consumers safety and ethical issues are some of the major obstacles of nanomaterials. The potential toxicological effects of nanomaterials on biological system including human health have so far not well studied (Donofrio, 2006). Some of the recent studies revealed that nanomaterials might impose the toxicological effects on biological systems (Zhang, Xu, Bertrand, Pridgen, Swami, & Farokhzad, 2012). Further, the existing laws, safety testingmethods are inadequate tomeasure the potential risks posed by the use of food exposed to nano-based chemicals. Keeping these point in view, a number of initiative have been taken to address the negative impact of nanomaterials on the health and environmental by the regulatory authorities such as Environment Protection Agency (EPA), Food and Drug Administration (FDA), UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs and nuclear protection agency etc., Therefore, there is strict need of further research on toxicological impact of nanomaterials into organism system before their wide application as delivery agents of the plant based preservative in food system.

sections.heading: 6. Concluding remarks
sections.text:
The global demand for safe and healthy food with minimal synthetic preservatives is increasing day by day especially by the health and environmentally concern consumers. In this context, EOs and their bioactive compounds possess strong antimicrobial activity could play a remarkable role as a novel source of food preservative. The use of modern scientific approaches viz., combinatorial chemistry, metabolic engineering and newer extraction methods have generated the novel source of raw materials with high yield thus expanded the application domain of EOs as antimicrobial agents. Further, the recent advancement in nanotechnology offers great opportunity to develop novel carrier agents for the delivery and control release of EOs based preservatives in food system with enhanced chemical, oxidative and thermal stability. Although, nanoencapsulation is one of the promising tools for effective delivery of EOs into food, the toxicological aspects of most of the nanocarriers and their molecular target site are yet poorly explored. Hence, the physiochemical interactions of nanoencapsulated EOs with food system and their toxicological impacts
need to be investigated before their commercial application. Therefore, future research must be directed towards the synthesis of novel synergistic formulation based on EOs and their nanoencapsulation to reduce the adverse effects on organoleptic properties with improve antimicrobial potency in the food matrix.

metadata.abstractText: Plant essential oils (EOs) possesses remarkable antimicrobial efficacy and therefore have great potential as an alternative of health hazardous synthetic preservatives. In spite of marvellous efficacy, their application yet not widely used by the food industries due to some of the major intrinsic obstacles viz., low water solubility, bioavailability, volatility and stability in the food system. The recent advancement in nanotechnology has potential to address these existing obstacles of EOs as preservatives in the food system. The applications of nanomaterials as a carrier agent of EOs recently gain momentum of interest by the food industries to improve their shelf-life and preservatives efficacy at low doses. Nanoemulsions, microemulsions, solid-lipid nanoparticles and liposomes are some of the currently used encapsulation strategies to encapsulate plant bioactive compounds. In this review, we explored the potential application of nanoencapsulated plant EOs as novel source of food preservatives. In addition, the prospects, existing limitations and future research direction for their commercialization are also discussed. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
